info.game_comments:
2008 College Championship quarterfinal game 3.
From the Kohl Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

double_jeopardy_round: I'M GOING TO BE A JUNIOR

(1, 1).clue: In a Defoe novel, this companion is described as "a comely handsome fellow"

(2, 1).clue: "Rudy" featured Jason Miller as this university's coach Ara Parseghian

(3, 1).clue: This is the official religion of Libya

(4, 1).clue: For warmth & a folksy effect, I use a 19th century hooked one of these, which were often made from old feed bags

(5, 1).clue: These semi-aquatic rodents plaster their lodges with mud

(6, 1).clue: This Atlantic City promenade was built in 1870 as a temporary structure

(1, 2).clue: "Jo's Boys" was the second sequel to this 19th century novel

(2, 2).clue: Bear Bryant puts this speedy title character of a 1994 movie on the Crimson Tide

(3, 2).clue: The geographic center of this state is Kent, 11 miles south of Dover

(4, 2).clue: My parties on the theme of this traditional feast are historically authentic, with ti leaves & lauhala mats

(5, 2).clue: The army species of this insect has no permanent home; workers link legs to protect their queen

(6, 2).clue: A benevolent & protective order was named in 1868 for this animal

(1, 3).clue: Chapter 48 of this English novel deals with "The Flight of Sikes"--Bill Sikes

(2, 3).clue: Shot at University of Wisconsin-Madison, "Back to School" features Rodney Dangerfield competing in this aquatic sport

(3, 3).clue: The endangered species list includes this spotted African cat plus a fish & a frog named for it

(4, 3).clue: Hope you like my towels with traditional block printing from Jaipur in this country

(5, 3).clue: The swiftlets of Asia are in trouble because these structures are snatched to make soup

(6, 3).clue: This president snagged Oregon for the United States

(1, 4).clue: Richard Middlemas gets crushed by an elephant in "The Surgeon's Daughter", an 1827 tale by this Edinburgher

(2, 4).clue: The premiere for this 2006 film featured a green carpet, to honor the Thundering Herd

(3, 4).clue: William Driver is said to have given this nickname to the American flag in 1824

(4, 4).clue: Originally, sequins were worn to show off one's wealth; the word "sequin" comes from the Arabic for this object

(5, 4).clue: This "solitary" crustacean sometimes defends its shell home via sea anemones that hitch a ride

(6, 4).clue: These maidens bring the souls of slain warriors to Valhalla

(1, 5).clue: The NYC murder of Mary Rogers inspired Poe, who changed the setting to Paris & created "The Mystery of" her

(2, 5).clue: In "Glory Road", Jon Voight played this school's legendary coach Adolph Rupp

(3, 5).clue: The Supreme Court rejected absolute executive privilege in the 1974 case United States v. this man

(4, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reads the clue.)Making ordinary furniture look like an antique is called this, a synonym for "troubling"--the fun part is the hitting

(5, 5).clue: Insert a hyphen in this 4-letter poultry dwelling & you get a human dwelling

(6, 5).clue: Seen here are the shells of this type of marine snail

(1, 1).clue: This "colorful" Ivy League college was founded in 1764

(2, 1).clue: Last name of the pere who wrote "The Three Musketeers" & the fils who wrote "Francillon"

(3, 1).clue: In February 2008, someone edited Hillary Clinton's entry on this website, replacing her picture with one of a walrus

(4, 1).clue: Known for his streak of consecutive games played, he made baseball's Hall of Fame in 2007 with 98.5% of the vote

(5, 1).clue: Golda Meir began serving as this country's prime minister at age 70

(6, 1).clue: It's a 7-letter word for a fellow Communist Party member, Tovarich

(1, 2).clue: This Wisconsin school was the first Catholic university to admit women

(2, 2).clue: He's the title Antoine de Saint-Exupery character seen here

(3, 2).clue: For April Fool's Day 1998, Burger King announced a new left-handed one of these, with the toppings rotated 180°

(4, 2).clue: Hey hey hey! He's the junior seen here

(5, 2).clue: Once featured on a U.S. coin, she was past 80 when she founded the International Woman Suffrage Alliance

(6, 2).clue: Dude! This totally means favoring extreme political reforms...whoa! It's also a math term? Righteous!

(1, 3).clue: This D.C. school adopted the colors gray & blue to symbolize the reunification of the nation after the Civil War

(2, 3).clue: His 1843 play "The Burgraves" failed miserably, but his 1862 novel "Les Miserables" was a smash

(3, 3).clue: Seen here are Washington Huskies fans, victims of the old flip-card switcheroo, at this bowl game in 1961

(4, 3).clue: We'll show you the money if you know this star's TD dance in "Jerry Maguire" was choreographed by Paula Abdul

(5, 3).clue: This English physicist was working as Master of the Mint at his death at age 84 in 1727

(6, 3).clue: It means to give up a fugitive to another nation

(1, 4).clue: In the 1890s Marshall Field donated land for this city-named university

(2, 4).clue: To speak "Candide"-ly, in 1717 this author was imprisoned in the Bastille

(3, 4).clue: In 1933 Harvard hooligans fishnapped the "Sacred" this, a carving in the Massachusetts State House

(4, 4).clue: This country star sang the Monday Night Football theme song for ABC from 1989 to 2005

(5, 4).clue: When his son Robert E. Lee was born, this Revolutionary War hero was more than 50 years old

(6, 4).clue: To sit with one leg on each side, as on a horse

(1, 5).clue: After a millionaire was murdered by his valet, this Houston univ. that he endowed got to open its doors sooner

(2, 5).clue: Get an "F" in literature & name this author who penned "Madame Bovary"

(3, 5).clue: In 1805 this frontier novelist was kicked out of Yale, possibly for seating a donkey in a professor's chair

(4, 5).clue: This junior is an excellent driver--he won the 2004 Daytona 500

(5, 5).clue: This Italian composer wrote his opera "Falstaff" when he was 79 years old

(0, 0).clue: Only 50 years old when he left office, he was our nation's youngest ex-president
